title: Giovanni Galeone
text:
Giovanni Galeone (born 25 January 1941) is an Italian <a href="association%20football">football</a> manager and former player.
Playing career.
Galeone, born in Naples, moved to Northern Italy in his youth years, and played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> for <a href="A.S.D.%20Ponziana">Ponziana Trieste</a>, <a href="A.C.%20Monza%20Brianza%201912">Monza</a> and <a href="Udinese%20Calcio">Udinese</a>, where he spent most of his playing career.
Managerial career.
Galeone started his coaching career at 34 for <a href="Serie%20D">Serie D</a> team <a href="Pordenone%20Calcio%20S.S.D.">Pordenone</a>, in 1975–76, obtaining an eleventh place in his debut season. His first coaching experience in a professional league came in the 1978–79 season for <a href="U.S.%20Cremonese">Cremonese</a> of <a href="Serie%20C">Serie C1</a>, but ended with a sacking. After a few other experiences, including three fairly successful seasons at <a href="Spal%201907">SPAL</a> of Serie C1, in 1986–87 Galeone signed for <a href="Serie%20B">Serie B</a> team <a href="Pescara%20Calcio">Pescara</a>, the team whose name is associated with him still today. In his debut season with Pescara, Galeone won Serie B and led his team directly to <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> , and managed to save Pescara from relegation the following season for the first time ever for his side. He left Pescara in 1988–89, after having failed to avoid relegation for his second time, but returned in 1990–91 and regained promotion to Serie A in 1991–92. Other than Pescara, where he coached also in 1999–2000 and 2000–01, Galeone served as head coach for <a href="Udinese%20Calcio">Udinese Calcio</a> in 1994–95, obtaining a Serie A promotion, <a href="Perugia%20Calcio">Perugia</a> in 1995–96, where he obtained his fourth and final Serie A promotion, <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a> in 1997–98 and <a href="A.C.%20Ancona">Ancona</a> in 2003–04. In 2006, Galeone made his comeback at Udinese, as he was called to replace <a href="Loris%20Dominissini">Loris Dominissini</a> and <a href="Roberto%20N%C3%A9stor%20Sensini">Néstor Sensini</a> at the helm of the "bianconeri".
Galeone is well known for being a strong advocate for the <a href="Formation%20%28association%20football%29%234%E2%80%933%E2%80%933">4–3–3 formation</a>, <a href="zonal%20marking">zonal marking</a>, and an attacking style of playing, which made of him one of the most innovative Italian football coaches in the late 1980s alongside <a href="Arrigo%20Sacchi">Arrigo Sacchi</a>. At 65, he had been the oldest active head coach in the 2006–07 Serie A, before being fired on 16 January after disagreements with the club.
On 19 July 2007, he was announced to make a fourth comeback at Pescara, this time as technical consultant beside new boss <a href="Andrea%20Camplone">Andrea Camplone</a>, a former player of his in the 1990s, but left the club only one month later.
